Why are you getting married in Santa Fe?: Why are you getting married in Santa Fe?
Sarah grew up in Atlanta, but her parent: Sarah grew up in Atlanta, but her parents have lived in Albuquerque for the past 15 years. New Mexico feels like home. Santa Fe is a special place -- a beautiful, ancient city (the oldest capitol in the U.S.)
So, when should I get there?: So, when should I get there?
Most guests are arriving on Friday, June: Most guests are arriving on Friday, June 23. We're hosting a welcome dinner in Santa Fe on Friday evening, and you should come!(Click here to RSVP.)
Which airport should I fly into?: Which airport should I fly into?
Albuquerque's International Sunport (yes: Albuquerque's International Sunport (yes, Sunport!) is your best bet. Santa Fe has an airport, but flights there are pricier.
Which airlines will get me there?: Which airlines will get me there?
A bunch of airlines offer nonstop and co: A bunch of airlines offer nonstop and connecting service to Albuquerque. It's usually best to check Southwest first. Delta, American, and United also offer nonstop flights from various U.S. cities.
OK. How do I get from Albuquerque to San: OK. How do I get from Albuquerque to Santa Fe?
Santa Fe is about an hour's drive northe: Santa Fe is about an hour's drive northeast of Albuquerque. You can rent a car in Albuquerque, or you can take the Sandia Shuttle from the Sunport directly to our wedding hotel (the ride costs $55 per person roundtrip and takes about 75 minutes). Another option is to take the Rail Runner train from Albuquerque to Santa Fe. The train ride is beautiful (and cheap), but just keep in mind that you'll need to take a shuttle or taxi to the Albuquerque train station from the Sunport.
But won't I need a car in Santa Fe?: But won't I need a car in Santa Fe?
Santa Fe is quite walkable, and our wedd: Santa Fe is quite walkable, and our wedding hotel has a free shuttle that takes you within a one-mile radius of the hotel. A car is definitely nice if you plan to do any hiking or want to roam farther away from the city, but it's not necessary.
Yes! We've reserved a block of rooms at: Yes! We've reserved a block of rooms at the Hotel Santa Fe, Hacienda and Spa, which is a 15-minute walk from our wedding and reception venue. To reserve a room, please call (855) 825-9876 and ask for the Karon-Mirosa rate. They'll also honor the discount one day before (Thursday) and after (Sunday) the wedding weekend. The discount is available until Tuesday, May 23.
What types of rooms are available? How m: What types of rooms are available? How much money are we talking?
Traditional rooms (with either a king or: Traditional rooms (with either a king or two double beds) cost $159 per night, and that rate includes breakfast, internet, parking, the aforementioned shuttle, and a 15 percent discount on spa treatments. Suites are a little jazzier (sofa! coffee table!) and cost $179 per night. King rooms in the Hacienda side of the hotel, which is fancier (and where celebs stay when they're in town filming) cost $189 per night. The hotel has photos of its room options on its website.
I called the hotel, but there aren't any: I called the hotel, but there aren't any rooms left in the block.
Please call or text us if this happens!: Please call or text us if this happens! We can add more rooms so that you can get the discount.
We're thinking about extending our stay: We're thinking about extending our stay in Santa Fe. Can we get a discount on our room?
Yes! The hotel will honor the discounted: Yes! The hotel will honor the discounted rate one day before and after the wedding weekend.
Check out El Rey, the Santa Fe Motel and: Check out El Rey, the Santa Fe Motel and Inn, and the Silver Saddle Motel. The Santa Fe Motel and Inn is about a 10-minute walk from the wedding venue. If you stay at El Rey or the Silver Saddle, you'll need to drive or Uber to the wedding venue (it's about a 10- to 15-minute drive).
What should I pack for this high desert: What should I pack for this high desert getaway?
Santa Fe is hot in June, with average hi: Santa Fe is hot in June, with average high temperatures in the upper 80s. (It's a dry heat, though!) The ceremony and reception will be in the evening, and will take place both inside and outside (on grass), if that affects your choice of footwear. Just wear shoes you can dance in!
And what exactly is the \"high desert\"?: And what exactly is the "high desert"?
Santa Fe has an elevation of 7,200 feet: Santa Fe has an elevation of 7,200 feet (2,200 meters), so if you don't live at high altitude, you might have a slight headache on the first day. Drink lots of water and pop an ibuprofen if needed.
Sarah grew up in Atlanta, but her parent: Sarah grew up in Atlanta, but her parents have lived in Albuquerque for the past 15 years. New Mexico feels like home. Santa Fe is a special place — a beautiful, ancient city (the oldest capitol in the U.S.)
Most guests are arriving on Friday, June: Most guests are arriving on Friday, June 23. We're hosting a welcome dinner in Santa Fe on Friday evening, and you should come! (Click here to RSVP.)
Good question! Very, VERY good question.
Okay. So, Sarah grew up in Atlanta and c: Okay. So, Sarah grew up in Atlanta and consequently lived in Southern California, England, Berkeley, Southern California, San Francisco, Costa Rica, Wisconsin, Iowa, Vermont, Wisconsin, and now Atlanta, in that order. Oriol, meanwhile, grew up in Barcelona and consequently lived in New York, Ecuador, Barcelona, England, Wisconsin, Bolivia, South Africa, and Wisconsin, in that order. So, of course, Santa Fe made sense.
Really, though, Sarah's parents have liv: Really, though, Sarah's parents have lived in Albuquerque for 15 years, so New Mexico has become a special place. Also Santa Fe is really beautiful, and strikes a nice balance between "destination" and "close to home."

The ceremony and reception will be held: The ceremony and reception will be held at the Gerald Peters Gallery, in the Peters Projects space. The address is 1011 Paseo De Peralta, Santa Fe, NM 87501. Click here for a map.

Our first conversation was about our sha: Our first conversation was about our shared love of travel, and we can't think of a better way to begin our married life than exploring a new place together.

Atlanta, 1986: Bowl cuts and drawing cla: Atlanta, 1986: Bowl cuts and drawing class, dinosaurs and She-Ra, climbing magnolia trees and pestering her older sister. Life was pretty sweet for this seven-year-old.
Barcelona, 1981: soccer matches and Spid: Barcelona, 1981: soccer matches and Spiderman, bikes and video games, chocolate biscuits and Star Wars on Betamax — that's all this six-year-old cared about.
A theater nerd, writer, and chronic proc: A theater nerd, writer, and chronic procrastinator, she was obsessed with Jane Austen and My So-Called Life. She fled the South for California, and then Central America, before following her older sister to... Wisconsin.
His soft-spokenness and impeccable manne: His soft-spokenness and impeccable manners hid a love for death metal and socialism. He was a guitarist and straight-A student, an activist and volunteer, destined to travel the world and wind up in... Wisconsin.

She met him two weeks before he was leav:
She met him two weeks before he was leaving town, struck by his intelligence, passion, and determination to dance with (near) her.

Four days later, they were inseparable.
He met her during her carefree summer, s:
He met her during her carefree summer, struck by her charm, wit, and the way she could clear a dance floor. On their first date, he told himself:

"I can see myself happy with her in 40 years."

Our welcome dinner is Friday, June 23 (<: Our welcome dinner is Friday, June 23 (click here to RSVP), but we encourage you to arrive in Santa Fe earlier if you want to enjoy a longer vacation! Our wedding hotel offers an extended discount on guestrooms (more on that below).

Again, yes! The hotel will honor the dis: Again, yes! The hotel will honor the discounted rate three days before and after the wedding weekend (from Monday, June 19, until Tuesday, June 27).
Clafoutis: A French cafe and bakery, wit: Clafoutis: A French cafe and bakery, with delicious freshly made beignets only available on Saturdays.
If you can spend more than a weekend in: If you can spend more than a weekend in beautiful Santa Fe, we encourage you to arrive earlier to enjoy a longer vacation! Our wedding hotel also offers an extended discount on guestrooms (more on that below).
The gallery is a 15-minute walk from our: The gallery is a 15-minute walk from our wedding hotel (read more about the hotel here). You can also Uber to the gallery, or, if you choose to drive, there's plenty of free parking.
A French cafe and bakery, with delicious: A French cafe and bakery, with delicious freshly made beignets only available on Saturdays.
Don't miss their huge homemade cinnamon: Don't miss their huge homemade cinnamon rolls, only available Wednesday, Saturday, and Sunday. They also serve soup and sandwiches.
Minimal food options, but tasty coffee.
There's always a line, but this is our f: There's always a line, but this is our favorite for quintessential New Mexican dishes.
Stop by this food truck for spicy, flavo: Stop by this food truck for spicy, flavorful, and pretty damn amazing burritos and tacos. Open for breakfast and lunch only.
A Santa Fe institution, known for having: A Santa Fe institution, known for having the best chile (which you can also buy by the jar). Prepare to wait in line, or grab a spot at the bar and sip one of their margaritas. They also serve breakfast.
Famous sopapillas and New Mexican home c: Famous sopapillas and New Mexican home cooking (just FYI, the sopapillas are only served at lunch, not breakfast). For a hearty breakfast with a spicy kick, order the breakfast burrito with "Christmas" (red and green) chile.
Classic New Mexican fare, with vegetaria: Classic New Mexican fare, with vegetarian and gluten-free options.
Fabulous freshly made bread and deliciou: Fabulous freshly made bread and delicious sandwiches. Bonus: Sage is across the street from our wedding hotel!
Beautiful ambiance and wonderful Souther: Beautiful ambiance and wonderful Southern Indian fare. Be sure to try their salted lemonade.
Worth the short trek out of town, and do: Worth the short trek out of town, and don't be fooled by the strip mall facade. A local favorite serving a mix of Swahili, Indian, Arabic, and European influenced cuisine, and they have the best chai in town. Vegetarian, vegan, and gluten-free dishes available.
Another food truck, this time serving As: Another food truck, this time serving Asian tacos (picture Bulgogi meat, ginger, guacamole, jicama... yum). Open for a late breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Twenty different salads, plus sandwiches: Twenty different salads, plus sandwiches and soups. Vegetarian, vegan, and gluten-free options. Open for lunch and dinner.
Check out their cozy bar and delicious c: Check out their cozy bar and delicious cocktails.
Small plates and craft cocktails. Pricey: Small plates and craft cocktails. Pricey but worth it if you're in the mood to splurge.
Spanish tapas with a nice selection of M: Spanish tapas with a nice selection of Mediterranean and South American wines.
Locally sourced ingredients and lots of: Locally sourced ingredients and lots of vegetarian, vegan, and gluten-free options. Try their Thai Nights on Wednesday through Saturday evenings.
The El Salvadorian papusas are a must-tr: The El Salvadorian papusas are a must-try at this family-friendly cafe. A great local hang-out with cozy ambiance.
We never leave Santa Fe without stopping: We never leave Santa Fe without stopping by Kakawa! This local favorite is a specialty chocolate shop with recipes that harken back to 1,000 BC. Try their truffles, caramels, hot chocolate mixes, renowned chocolate-dipped chile pods — and the best iced mochas, ever.
An ice-cream shop known for unique flavo: An ice-cream shop known for unique flavor combinations and local ingredients.
You can easily spend a week in and aroun: You can easily spend a week in and around Santa Fe. Here are some of our favorite in-town activities:
Located downtown, Santa Fe's Spanish Col: Located downtown, Santa Fe's Spanish Colonial plaza was established in 1609. The Native artisans who sell silver, turquoise, and crafts on the north end of the plaza all come from local Pueblos, and all their crafts are handmade. The plaza is home to St. Francis Cathedral and the Palace of the Governors, a museum that's also the oldest continuously used building in the United States.
Right off the plaza, this museum is smal: Right off the plaza, this museum is small and lovely, and dedicated to the artist's legacy and American Modernism (O'Keeffe spent the latter half of her life in New Mexico).
Located about two miles from the plaza,: Located about two miles from the plaza, Museum Hill is home to four excellent museums &emdash; the Museum of Indian Arts & Culture, the Museum of International Folk Art, the Wheelwright Museum of the American Indian, and the Museum of Spanish Colonial Art. We love their botanical garden, too.
Aside from New York, Santa Fe has more a: Aside from New York, Santa Fe has more art galleries than any city in the United States. Canyon Road is only a half-mile long and boasts more than one hundred galleries, boutiques, and restaurants.
(now East de Vargas Street): Just steps: (now East de Vargas Street): Just steps away from Canyon Road, and one of the country's oldest continuously inhabited streets.
One of the best galleries in Santa Fe, a: One of the best galleries in Santa Fe, and one of our favorites; don't miss the beautiful sculpture garden. And it's across the street from Kakawa Chocolate House!
Just outside of downtown, the Railyard D: Just outside of downtown, the Railyard District is filled with art spaces, cafes, and shopping. Check out the Santa Fe Farmers' Market or stop by Second Street Brewery for a beer and one of their tasty green chile cheeseburgers.
There are dozens of day-hike options in: There are dozens of day-hike options in and around Santa Fe. For a wonderful day hike, head to Kasha-Katuwe Tent Rocks National Monument, 50 minutes southwest of Santa Fe. There you can do an easy 1.2-mile hike or a moderate-to-challenging 3-mile hike on Tent Rocks Trail, which offers gorgeous views of striated rock formations, the famous hoodoos (tent rocks), the Sangre de Cristo, Jemez, and Sandia mountains, and the Rio Grande Valley. Wherever you hike, be sure to carry water and bring layers; the weather can change rapidly as you ascend and descend.
If you make a pastime of pampering, head: If you make a pastime of pampering, head to this beautiful Japanese-style spa with forest-view hot tubs and Asian-style massages. The spa is 10 miles outside of Santa Fe and located on a mountain overlooking the city. You can enjoy a communal tub or sauna, rent a private tub, book a massage or facial, and dine at their James Beard-nominated Japanese restaurant, Izanami. Book at least a few weeks in advance, as spots tend to fill up quickly.
Sarah and her sister Amy stayed here way:
Sarah and her sister Amy stayed here way back in 1998! A mineral hot springs and hotel, Ojo Caliente is lovely for a day trip or overnight stay. You can float in the hot springs, enjoy a massage or mud bath, dine at their restaurant, and stay overnight in either their newer accommodations or historic 1916 hotel. Ojo Caliente is about an hour's drive north of Santa Fe.
  • The High Road from Santa Fe to Taos: This route offers a combination of New Mexicana and panoramic views. The trip takes about two hours without stopping, but it's worth visiting several towns along the way where time has stood still. These include
famous for its Sanctuario de Chimayó (a: famous for its Sanctuario de Chimayó (a pilgrimage site for many Hispanic Catholics) and traditional weaving galleries (visit Trujillo's)
two towns up the road, has been settled: two towns up the road, has been settled by many artists and is home to several galleries.
home to the fabulous Sugar Nymph's Bistr: home to the fabulous Sugar Nymph's Bistro, started by a couple who left the San Francisco food scene to pursue dreams of a small-town cafe. Make time for lunch or cake!
When you get to Taos, be sure to visit t: When you get to Taos, be sure to visit the Pueblo, the only living Native American community designated both a World Heritage Site by UNESCO and a National Historic Landmark. The multi-storied adobe buildings have been continuously inhabited for over 1,000 years. When you're done exploring Taos, you can halve your return journey by taking the Low Road, along the Rio Grande River, back to Santa Fe.
About an hour's drive west of Santa Fe,: About an hour's drive west of Santa Fe, this impressive Monument contains 23,000 acres of backcountry wilderness, waterfalls, and wildlife. It's best known for the remarkable petroglyphs carved into the nooks and crevices of the canyon wall above the dwellings by ancestral Puebloans.
Georgia O'Keeffe's famed ranch in Abiqui: Georgia O'Keeffe's famed ranch in Abiquiú, which served as the setting for many of her paintings, can be toured by appointment on Tuesdays, Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays. If you're interested in visiting, we recommend booking well ahead of time. Check out the nearby Abiquiú Inn for a meal or overnight stay. Abiquiú is about an hour's drive north of Santa Fe.
When it comes to restaurants, Santa Fe h: When it comes to restaurants, Santa Fe has an embarrassment of riches. Here are some tips for anyone new to New Mexican cooking:
You'll find chile all over menus, in eve: You'll find chile all over menus, in everything from enchiladas to ice cream.
Chile comes in green and red, and is typ: Chile comes in green and red, and is typically served as a sauce. Not sure of the heat level? Just ask your server.
Sopapillas, another local staple, are a: Sopapillas, another local staple, are a Native American fried dough served with honey.
Posole is a a chile and pork stew served: Posole is a a chile and pork stew served with hominy.
Posole is a chile and pork stew served w: Posole is a chile and pork stew served with hominy.
Kids are welcome! However, we know that: Kids are welcome! However, we know that sometimes you want to party without them. Depending on how many children come to Santa Fe, we'll arrange a kids' room at our wedding hotel or a kids' area at our reception (staffed by reliable babysitters, of course). Please contact us if you'd be interested in a childcare option.
Armed with a killer bowlcut and winsome: Armed with a killer bowlcut and winsome overbite, she loved She-Ra and magnolia trees, dinosaurs and drawing class, Archie comics and Lima beans.
Halfway across the world, he was faring: Halfway across the world, he was faring better in the hair department. He loved soccer and Spiderman, bikes and video games, chocolate biscuits and Star Wars on Betamax.

Located about two miles from the plaza,: Located about two miles from the plaza, Museum Hill is home to four excellent museums — the Museum of Indian Arts & Culture, the Museum of International Folk Art, the Wheelwright Museum of the American Indian, and the Museum of Spanish Colonial Art. We love their botanical garden, too.
Santa Fe is about an hour's drive northe: Santa Fe is about an hour's drive northeast of Albuquerque. You can rent a car in Albuquerque, or you can take the Sandia Shuttle from the Sunport directly to our wedding hotel (the ride costs $55 per person roundtrip and takes about 75 minutes). Another option is to take the Rail Runner train from Albuquerque to Santa Fe. The train ride is beautiful (and cheap), but just keep in mind that you'll need to take a shuttle or taxi to the Albuquerque train station from the Sunport.
Check out the Silver Saddle motel, which: Check out the Silver Saddle motel, which offers rates starting around $65 per night. Just keep in mind that the Silver Saddle is about four miles from our wedding venue, so you'll need to Uber or drive to the ceremony. Other Santa Fe budget hotels, including El Rey, offer rates that match those offered by our wedding hotel.
